title: 105_hr4258
content: The "No Second Chances for Murderers, Rapists, or Child Molesters Act of 1998" mandates harsh penalties for individuals convicted of murder, rape, or child sexual offenses. Congress believes murderers should face the death penalty or life imprisonment without parole, while rapists or child offenders should receive life imprisonment without parole. The "No Second Chances for Murderers, Rapists, or Child Molesters Act of 1998" imposes severe penalties for individuals convicted of murder, rape, or dangerous sexual offenses. If a person with a prior conviction for these crimes in another state is convicted again, the Attorney General will transfer funds to compensate victims and cover the costs of incarceration, prosecution, and apprehension. The "No Second Chances for Murderers, Rapists, or Child Molesters Act of 1998" mandates severe penalties for individuals with prior convictions of murder, rape, or dangerous sexual offenses in multiple states. The Attorney General will transfer funds from Federal law enforcement assistance to compensate victims and cover costs of incarceration, prosecution, and apprehension. The "No Second Chances for Murderers, Rapists, or Child Molesters Act of 1998" mandates severe penalties for individuals with prior convictions of murder, rape, or dangerous sexual offenses in multiple states. Funds will be transferred from Federal law enforcement assistance to compensate victims and cover costs of incarceration, prosecution, and apprehension. States must apply for funds by submitting an application to the Attorney General, certifying the conviction of a person for specified crimes. The Act mandates severe penalties for individuals with prior convictions of murder, rape, or dangerous sexual offenses in multiple states. Funds will be transferred from Federal law enforcement assistance to compensate victims and cover costs of incarceration, prosecution, and apprehension. The amount transferred will be derived by reducing funds from Federal law enforcement assistance programs received by the State that convicted the offender. The Attorney General, in consultation with the chief executive of the convicting State, will develop a payment schedule. This section does not affect court-ordered restitution. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend guidelines to impose death or life imprisonment for murder and life imprisonment for rape or dangerous sexual offenses. Additionally, there will be a collection of recidivism data. The Attorney General will collect recidivism data on murders, rapes, and dangerous sexual offenses committed by repeat offenders. This data will be distributed to various government entities and institutions. The Act defines murder as the unlawful killing of a human being with malice aforethought, including premeditated killings and murders committed during certain crimes. Rape is defined as forcible carnal knowledge against the victim's will. The Act defines dangerous sexual offenses as sexual abuse or sexually explicit conduct by an individual over 18 against a child under 14, including coercion and exploitation of children. Sexually explicit conduct includes actual or simulated sexual intercourse. The Act defines dangerous sexual offenses as various forms of sexual contact, including genital-genital, oral-genital, anal-genital, bestiality, masturbation, lascivious exhibition, and sadistic or masochistic abuse. Sexual contact is defined as intentional touching of specific body parts with the intent to abuse, humiliate, harass, degrade, or arouse sexual desire.
